I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based  loan  (PBL)  to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  subprogram  3  of  the  Financial  Market 
Development and Inclusion Program (FMDIP). 
 
2. 
The  program  supports  the  main  reform  priorities  of  the  government  and  the  Financial 
Services  Authority  (OJK)  to  further  develop  and  make  the  finance  sector  more  inclusive  by  
(i) strengthening the regulatory structure for financial stability, (ii) deepening the financial market, 
and  (iii)  enhancing  financial  inclusion. 1  Subprogram  3  is  included  in  the  country  operations 
business plan of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 2019–2021 for Indonesia.2 The proposed 
subprogram  is  also  aligned  with  the  first  two  operational  priorities  of  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  to 
address poverty and reduce inequalities, and to accelerate progress in gender equality.3 
 

II. 

PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 

Background and Development Constraints 

 
A. 
 
3. 
The  programmatic  approach  and  budget  support.  FMDIP  uses  a  programmatic 
approach, which aligns ADB’s support with the government’s reform program over a medium-to 
long-term  horizon.  The  programmatic  approach  which  consisted  of  three  subprograms  and 
subprogram  1  amounting  to  $400  million  were  approved  by  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors  in 
September 2015.4 Subprogram 1 included 23 policy actions, focused on institutionalizing OJK as 
an  integrated  and  independent  financial  services  regulator  and  implementing  best  practices  in 
capital market development. Subprogram 2 was approved in June 2017 with a loan of $400 million 
and comprised of 25 policy actions. It supported the development of OJK’s consolidated finance 
sector master plan, which focused on making the sector stable, inclusive, and contributive to the 
economy.  It  also  advanced  OJK’s  fiscal  independence  and  legal  immunity,  and  began  ADB’s 
engagement  in  financial  inclusion.5 All  completed  policy  actions  in  subprograms  1  and  2  have 
been  sustained.  The  focus  of  Subprogram  3  is  on  implementing  the  master  plan,  expanding 
capital  market  products  and  services,  and  advancing  financial  inclusion  using  financial 
technology.  The  inclusion  of  the  post-program  partnership  framework  (P3F),  2019–2024  will 
enable  ADB  to  continue  supporting  finance  sector  reforms  and  provides  the  platform  for  a 
subsequent financial inclusion-focused program in 2021.   
 
4. 
The  development  problem.  Indonesia’s  annual  gross  domestic  product  (GDP) growth 
averaged 5.0% during 2014–2017. Growth picked up to 5.2% in 2018 from 5.1% in 2017, with 
potential growth estimated at 5.7% for 2020–2024.6 However, the government needs to balance 
sustained growth with stability, while reducing inequality to meet the development targets in its 
national medium-term development plan.7

High  inequality  remains  a  major  development  challenge.  Income  inequality  as 
5. 
measured by the Gini coefficient declined from 0.410 in 2014 to 0.384 in 2018, while the poverty 
rate  declined  from  11.3%  in  2014  to  9.7%  in  2018,  reaching  single  digits  for  the  first  time. 
Nevertheless, close to 40% of the population remains close to the national poverty line and are 
vulnerable  to  slipping  back  into  poverty.  In  addition,  regional  disparity  remains  a  significant 
problem. For example, the per capita income in Jakarta (about Rp158 million) is 13 times higher 
than  in  East  Nusa  Tenggara.  Recent  improvements  in  revenue  mobilization  has  enabled  the 
government to significantly expand social assistance programs and regional transfers. However, 
the fiscal impact of large external shocks, such as the natural disasters in Central Sulawesi and 
Lombok in 2018 can put this at risk.8 
 
6. 
Financial exclusion is directly linked to inequality. Lack of access to financial products 
and  services  deprives  the  poor  of  income  and  livelihood  opportunities  and  exposes  them  to 
financial  risks  arising  from  natural  disasters  and  economic  shocks.9 Indonesia  has  increased 
financial  inclusion  more  than  its  regional  comparators  from  2011  to  2017  (Figure  1).  The 
proportion of the adult population with a formal bank account was 49% in 2017, compared with 
36% in 2014 and 20% in 2011.10 Similarly, access to formal bank accounts by the poorest 40% 
of population in Indonesia increased to 37% in 2017 from 22% in 2014, and Indonesia has made 
impressive gains  in women’s  access  to finance  (51%  in 2017 from  38%  in  2014).  Despite  this 
progress, over half of the adult population remains financially excluded. Inclusion levels among 
the  poorest  40%  of  the  population  and  women  are  considerably  lower  than  in  Malaysia  and 
Thailand  (Figure  2).  Over  one  third  of  the  unbanked  adult  population  in  Indonesia  considers 
distance  to  be  a  key  reason  for  not  having  a  formal  bank  account.  Close  to  70%  own  mobile 
phones,  highlighting  the  significant  opportunity  for  the  use  of  mobile  phone-based  financial 
technology  to  overcome  geographical  barriers  and  increase  financial  inclusion,  with  a  view  to 
reaching the target of 75% by 2019.

7. 
A deep and resilient finance sector is essential for efficient financial intermediation 
and  stable  economic  growth.  Indonesia’s  finance  sector  has  become  more  developed  and 
stable over the program’s implementation period (2013–2018). The finance sector (bank credit, 
stock market capitalization, and bonds) has grown from 103% of GDP in 2013 to about 117% of 
GDP in 2017. The trading volume of the bond market has also improved from an average of $66 
billion in 2015 to an average of $94 billion in 2018. Similarly, indicators of financial stability such 
as credit default swap spreads have declined from 2014 to 2018. However, some factors may still 
subject  the finance  sector  to  instability;  it  is  heavily  reliant  on  bank  intermediation,  and foreign 
ownership  of  the  government  bond  market  remains  relatively  high  at  about  38%.  Financial 
instability disrupts economic growth and impacts poor households disproportionately as they have 
fewer  and  less-diversified  assets.  Further  reforms  to  diversify  the  finance  sector,  including  by 
developing the capital market, are required to deepen the finance sector, strengthen its stability, 
and make it more inclusive. 
 
8. 
Binding  constraints.  The government  and  OJK  recognize  these  challenges  and  have 
identified three primary constraints: (i) an incomplete framework and coordination mechanism for 
financial stability; (ii) the shallow finance sector; and (iii) financial exclusion of poor households.11 
These constraints are discussed in paras. 9–13. 
 
9. 
Incomplete framework and coordination mechanism for financial stability. The Law 
on Prevention and Resolution of Financial System Crisis (Financial Stability Law) enacted in 2016 
was a significant reform in providing OJK with legal immunity that allows supervisors to perform 
their duty without fear of litigation. The law also provides OJK with the authority to require systemic 
banks to increase their capital to mitigate financial crises. However, several constraints remain. 
First, implementing regulations, including those governing recovery plans and resolutions, need 
to be adopted. Similarly, the borrowing criteria for the deposit insurance corporation (LPS) in the 
bank resolution process needs to be clarified. Second, integrated implementation of OJK’s master 
plan is required so that financial service providers offering the same services are treated similarly 
to avoid distortions  and regulatory  arbitrage. This  requires  coordination  through a crosscutting 
secretariat with a focus on the priority reform actions. Third, integrated supervision needs to be 
more holistic so that financial conglomerates are better supervised. Indonesia’s finance sector is 
characterized  by  the  strong  presence  of  financial  conglomerates,  some  having  a  horizontal 
ownership structure, which complicates supervision. Under the current regulatory framework, OJK 
does not  have access to information on  nonfinancial  holding  companies  because they  are  not 
licensed or regulated by OJK. 
 
Shallow finance sector. Notwithstanding recent finance sector growth (para. 7), it is still

dominated by banks. The size of the equity market in 2017 (51% of GDP) and market liquidity as 
measured by share turnover velocity (26%) are small relative to Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) comparators. Similarly, the size of the bond market equals 18% of GDP, with 
corporate bonds representing only 3% of GDP. 
 
11. 
Despite  strong  potential,  Indonesia’s  corporate  sukuk  (sharia  compliant  bond)  market 
represents just 4% of its overall sukuk market. A key constraint is uncertainty in relation to tax 
treatment.  Specifically,  to  comply  with  Islamic  finance  principles,  issuance  of  sukuk  requires 
multiple asset transfers; given the lack of clarity on tax treatment, there is a risk that value-added 
tax  (VAT)  will  be  charged  each  time  the  asset  is  transferred.  For  investors,  sukuk  investment 
returns may not be eligible for the same income tax deductions as their conventional counterparts. 
Therefore, corporate sukuks are less attractive to both potential issuers and investors. A recent

12. 
The government is committed to developing municipal bond markets, but the lack of legal 
certainty on audit requirements has constrained subnational government bond issuances. OJK’s 
2016  announcement  that  it  would  exempt  municipal  governments  from  undergoing  additional

double audit requirement increases the issuance cost for subnational governments. There is also 
a  need  for  clarity  on  the  content  of  the  bond  prospectus,  legal  documents  to  be  submitted  by 
subnational governments, and their post-issuance reporting obligations. 
 
13. 
Financial exclusion. With over 17,500 islands, Indonesia faces significant geographical 
challenges to  achieving financial  inclusion.  Constraints  include:  (i)  coordination  among  various 
government agencies and other stakeholders is lacking and limits the implementation of financial 
inclusion activities; (ii) the regulatory framework covers only peer-to-peer lending, with no overall 
regulatory framework for the financial technology industry; (iii) the number of branchless banks 
and  agents  is  insufficient  given  the  large  number  of  people  that  are  financially  excluded;  and  
(iv) a low level of financial literacy. The national financial literacy rate is 29%, with women having 
lower  literacy  than  men.  Furthermore,  the  lack  of  bank  services  in  marginalized  provinces, 
disproportionately affects women as they have greater mobility constraints.     
 
B. 
 
14. 
The government’s reform agenda. The government’s reform agenda is anchored in the 
National  Medium-Term  Development  Plan  for  2015–2019,  which  seeks  to  reduce  the  Gini 
coefficient to 0.36 and lower the poverty rate to 7%–8% by 2019 (footnote 7). The government 
recognizes  that  promoting  financial  stability,  deepening  the  financial  market,  and  improving 
access to financial services for the poor are integral to meeting these targets. The government’s 
strategy  consists  of  a  series  of  reforms,  including  implementing  OJK’s  mandate  as  an 
independent  and  integrated  regulator,  enacting  the  Financial  Stability  Law,  and  implementing 
regulations to safeguard financial stability. These reforms will be followed by measures to develop 
new  instruments  in  the  capital  market  and  a  stronger  focus  on  financial  inclusion  for  poor 
households. The government launched the National Financial Inclusion Strategy in August 2016, 
which sets an ambitious target for 75% of the adult population to have access to financial services 
by  2019. 12 In  addition,  based  on  the  recommendations  in  the  Financial  Sector  Assessment 
Program of 2017, the government also launched the National Financial Market Development and 
Deepening Strategy, 2018-2024 to anchor reforms in the finance sector.13 
 
15. 
Proposed  policy  reforms.  The  program  supports  the  following  reform  areas:  
(i)  regulatory  structure  for  financial  stability  strengthened;  (ii)  financial  market  deepened;  and  
(iii)  financial  inclusion  enhanced.  At  the  inception  of  subprogram  3,  the  government  agreed  to 
complete 10 prior actions (or triggers) and 12 policy milestones as the basis for subprogram 3.14 
During the processing of subprogram 3, a new prior action was added to reflect OJK’s approval 
of  green  bond  regulations  and  the  issuance  of  the  first  sovereign  green  sukuk.  The  policy 
milestones on municipal bonds and the expansion of national health insurance were upgraded to 
prior actions to emphasize the importance of coordination between the government and OJK to

16. 
Regulatory structure for financial stability strengthened. This reform area builds on 
accomplishments  in  subprograms  1  and  2 that  established  OJK  as  an  independent  integrated 
regulator,  enacted  the  Financial  Stability  Law  that  provided  OJK  with  legal  immunity,  and 
developed OJK’s consolidated master plan 2015–2019. There were three main accomplishments 
in subprogram 3. First, OJK advanced implementation of its master plan and completed 90% of 
priority reforms ahead of schedule, including thematic risk-based surveillance, and simplification 
of both the process and documentation for small-scale capital market issuances. The reforms in 
the master plan benefit women through the focus on financial inclusion and literacy. Monitoring of 
the master plan is coordinated through a central secretariat with quarterly reporting to the Board 
of Commissioners.  
 
17. 
Second, OJK issued three regulations to implement the Financial Stability Law adopting 
a risk-based approach to supervision by: (i) determining level of supervision based on the risk 
profile of each bank; (ii) providing procedures to establish bridge banks for orderly resolution of 
banks that cannot be recapitalized; and (iii) introducing a comprehensive regulatory framework 
on how systemic banks report to OJK. The Center of Financial Sector Policies (PKSK), Ministry 
of Finance (MOF) led government coordination efforts to safeguard financial stability, including 
the  issuance  of  regulations  (i)  to  allow  the  deposit  insurance  corporation  to  borrow  from  the 
government, and (ii) on procedures to write off assets for banking restructuring. Third, OJK has 
drafted  a  regulation  requiring  that  all  financial  conglomerates  set  up  holding  companies, 
effectively  converting  conglomerates 
into  vertical  structures  (a  holding  company  with 
subsidiaries). Integrated supervision, especially of financial conglomerates, provides OJK with a 
framework to monitor and mitigate operational and systemic risks. The outcome is an integrated 
risk rating for each financial conglomerate.

20. 
Financial  inclusion  enhanced.  This  reform  area  builds  on  accomplishments  during 
subprograms  1  and  2,  including  the  launch  of  the  branchless  banking  initiative  and  the 
establishment  of  the  National  Council  for  Financial  Inclusion  (NCFI).  There  were  four  major 
accomplishments under this output during subprogram 3. First, OJK approved expansion of the 
branchless banking initiative with a significant increase in the number of agents, cities and districts 
served,  which  help  provide  financial  services  to  marginalized  provinces  and  populations.  OJK 
also revised information collection for branchless banking to include sex-disaggregated data for 
agents  and  customers.  This  will  enable  banks  to  analyze  the  gender  profiles  of  agents  and 
customers to help banks improve their services. Measures were also taken to balance expansion 
and consumer protection. Participating banks are required to comply with strict security measures 
in the recruitment of agents, and to train and monitor them in order to prevent fraudulent activities. 
The effect of these reforms can be seen in the number of new account holders which increased 
significantly from approximately 5 million in 2017 to 22 million in 2018. 
 
21. 
Second, to improve financial literacy, OJK implemented online e-modules based on the 
textbooks approved by the Ministry of National Education for elementary, junior high, and senior 
high school students; and conducted 40 financial literacy programs targeting women, youth, and 
migrant workers. Third, OJK consolidated its financial inclusion and financial technology activities 
by  launching  the  OJK  Infinity  (Innovation  Centre  for  Digital  Financial  Technology)  to  promote 
collaboration among regulators, the government, and industries. Finally, OJK also issued digital 
finance  regulations  that  map  out  the  requirements  for  financial  technology  companies  to 
participate in the regulatory sandbox and detail the licensing and reporting requirements for equity 
crowd funding.  
 
22. 
Post-program partnership framework. The P3F provides for a structured dialogue over 
the medium term and represents a tripartite partnership between ADB, the government, and OJK 
to advance finance sector reforms supported by ADB’s technical assistance (TA).15 Key activities 
under the P3F include the development of a geospatial financial services mobile application to 
enhance  access  to  finance  by  enabling  consumers  to  locate  the  agents  providing  branchless 
banking, and the development of a 5-year financial technology road map. In addition, the P3F will 
focus  on  youth  and  include  activities  such  as  the  development  of  a  national  youth  financial 
inclusion strategy to promote access to finance for youth between 16 and 30 years of age.

The  impact  of  the  reform  program  is  demonstrated  by  performance  relative  to  the 
indicators in the DMF, which has exceeded the targets set during subprogram 1 (footnote 4). The 
size of the finance  sector  as  a  percentage  of GDP  has grown  by  approximately  14% (2014 to 
2017). Access to financial services for the poorest 40% has improved from 22% in 2014 to 37% 
in 2017. Therefore, the DMF targets for 2020 have been revised upwards. The program impact 
assessment estimates that the potential net present value of benefits of the program ranges from 
about $2.7 billion to $5.7 billion.21 Benefits are derived from reforms such as removal of VAT from 
sukuk, and reduction in government’s cost of borrowing through financial stability.

28. 
The government has requested a single tranche loan of $500 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 3.22 The loan will have a 15-year term, including a 
grace period of 3 years with straight-line repayment method; an annual interest rate determined 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan  agreement.  The  average  loan  maturity  is  9.25  years,  and  there  is  no  maturity  premium 
payable to ADB. The loan size is based on Indonesia’s financing needs, the development impact 
of the policy reform package, and development spending arising from the reforms. For 2019, the 
government’s projected total gross borrowing requirement is estimated at $59.6 billion. To finance 
the  deficit,  the  government  plans  to  raise  approximately  $53.4  billion  from  the  issuance  of 
securities, and approximately $5.9 billion from official development assistance.

33. 
is  macroeconomic  risk,  particularly  in  relation  to  tighter  global  financial  conditions.  This  is
